{{Infobox political party | name = Hayazn | logo = Hayazn logo.png | logo_size = 225px | colorcode = | leader = | president = | chairman = | secretary_general = | spokesperson = | ideology = [[Armenian nationalism]]{{cite news|script-title=hy:Երևանի ավագանու ընտրություններում «Հայազն» կուսակցության ցանկը Անդրեաս Ղուկասյանի գլխավորելու լուրը կեղծ է|url=http://www.tert.am/am/news/2013/03/19/hayazn/|accessdate=17 June 2014|work=[[tert.am]]|date=19 March 2013|language=hy|quote=...նորաստեղծ ազգայնական Հայազն կուսակցությունը...}}{{cite news|script-title=hy:Նոր ազգայնական կուսակցության մուտքը Հայաստանի քաղաքական դաշտ. «Հայազն»|url=http://www.emedia.am/?p=30259/nor+azgaynakan+kusakcutyan+mutgy+hayastani+gaxagakan+dasht+hayazn+fotosharg|accessdate=17 June 2014|date=31 January 2013|language=hy|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140617045308/http://www.emedia.am/?p=30259/nor+azgaynakan+kusakcutyan+mutgy+hayastani+gaxagakan+dasht+hayazn+fotosharg|archivedate=17 June 2014|df=}}
National Revolutionary (self-described){{cite news|script-title=hy:Հայազն-ը իրեն բնորոշում է որպես ազգային հեղափոխական կուսակցություն|url=http://168.am/2013/05/29/231174.html|accessdate=29 January 2014|newspaper=168|date=29 May 2013|language=hy}} | headquarters = [[Yerevan]], Armenia | website = {{url|http://www.hayazn.am/}} | country = Armenia | chairperson = | founder = Sergey Dalakyan, Sargis Chilincaryan, Hamlet Khamoyan, Heghine Sargsyan, Ani Sargsyan | slogan = | founded = 2009 (as an [[NGO]])
2013/2014 (as a political party) | newspaper = | paramilitary_wing = | membership_year = | membership = | seats1 = | seats2_title = | seats2 = | seats3_title = | seats3 = | seats4_title = | seats4 = | symbol = | flag = | country_dab1 = | parties_dab1 = | elections_dab1 = | country2 = | country_dab2 = | parties_dab2 = | elections_dab2 = | footnotes = }} '''Hayazn''' ({{lang-hy|Հայազն}}) is an [[Armenia]]n nationalist political party, that was founded as a civil organization in 2009.{{cite web|script-title=hy:««ՀԱՅԱԶՆ» ԵՐԻՏԱՍԱՐԴՆԵՐԻ ՄԻԱԲԱՆՈՒԹՅՈՒՆ » ՀԿ|url=https://www.e-register.am/am/companies/211115|publisher=Electronic Register, Government of the Republic of Armenia|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140617044452/https://www.e-register.am/am/companies/211115|archivedate=17 June 2014|language=hy}} It declared itself a political party in 2013 and was registered as such in 2014.{{cite web|script-title=hy:««ՀԱՅԱԶՆ»» ԿՍ|url=https://www.e-register.am/am/companies/967390|publisher=Electronic Register, Government of the Republic of Armenia|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140617044548/https://www.e-register.am/am/companies/967390|archivedate=17 June 2014|language=hy}} ==Ideology== Hayazn had stated its opposition to Armenia's possible integration into the [[European Union]] or to the [[Eurasian Customs Union]] that included at the time a customs union of Belarus, Kazakhstan and Russia]]. Hayazn had also called on the Armenian government to opt out of the [[European Neighbourhood Policy]] in the past.{{cite news|title="Հայազն". Հայաստանը պետք է դադարեցնի մասնակցությունը Եվրոպական միության "հարևանության" ծրագրին ''(Hayazn: Armenia should stop the participation in the European Neighbourhood Policy)''|url=http://www.panarmenian.net/arm/news/135851/|accessdate=13 December 2012|date=5 December 2012|agency=''[[PanARMENIAN.Net]]''|language=hy}} Hayazn also opposes any official recognition by Armenia of the [[Nagorno-Karabakh Republic]]. Instead Hayazn supports the actual unification of the Nagorno-Karabakh areas as an integral part of the Republic of Armenia, turning Karabakh into an additional Armenian province within the borders of an expanded Armenian Republic.{{cite news|title="Հայազն". Լեռնային Ղարաբաղի անկախության ճանաչումը սխալ է ''(Hayazn: Recognition of Artsakh is wrong)''|url=http://news.am/arm/news/121219.html|accessdate=13 December 2012|date=16 September 2012|agency=''News.am''|language=hy}}{{cite news|title=Հայազն Կուսակցության հայտարարությունը|url=http://www.lragir.am/index/arm/0/politics/view/84530|accessdate=20 June 2013|newspaper=Lragir|date=20 June 2013}} Hayazn also advocates in case of a war between Armenia and Azerbaijan, to "liberate" historical Armenian provinces of [[Ganja, Azerbaijan|Gandzak]] and [[Nakhchivan Autonomous Republic|Nakhitchevan]], presently within the territorial areas of Azerbaijan. In internal affairs, Hayazn is opposed to [[Serzh Sargsyan]]'s government and has condemned its internal and foreign policies, in particular the way it handles the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict within the [[OSCE Minsk Group]].{{cite news|title="Հայազն" միություն. Անհապաղ վերանայել "պատասխան գործողությունների" մեր չափանիշը ''(Hayazn: Government needs to revise its policy of response in the border zone)''|url=http://www.hraparak.am/68781/|accessdate=13 December 2012|date=6 June 2012|agency=''Hraparak''|language=hy|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130114174324/http://www.hraparak.am/68781/|archivedate=14 January 2013|df=}} The party called for a "no" vote in the [[Armenian constitutional referendum, 2015|2015 constitutional referendum]]{{cite news|last1=Nikoghosyan|first1=Alina|title=More "No" from Minor Political Party: Hayazn adds its voice to opposition over amendments|url=http://armenianow.com/news/constitution/67858/hayazn_political_party_shirak_torosyan_constitutional_amendments|work=ArmeniaNow|date=17 November 2015}} ==Activities== Although Hayazn was not registered as a political party, and couldn't legally participate in the [[Armenian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary election]], but nonetheless it refused to participate.{{cite news|title="Հայազն" միությունն ընտրություններին մասնակցելու իմաստ չի տեսնում ''(Hayazn Union sees no point in participating in the parliamentary election)''|url=http://hayeli.am/%D5%B0%D5%A1%D5%B5%D5%A1%D5%A6%D5%B6-%D5%B4%D5%AB%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B6%D5%B6-%D5%A8%D5%B6%D5%BF%D6%80%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%A9%D5%B5%D5%B8%D6%82%D5%B6%D5%B6%D5%A5%D6%80%D5%AB/|accessdate=13 December 2012|date=28 March 2012|agency=''Hayeli''|language=hy}} It blamed mainstream opposition parties ([[Armenian Revolutionary Federation]], [[Armenian National Congress]], [[Heritage (Armenia)|Heritage]]) for not being "pro-people", and the government for electoral fraud which resulted in the formation of, what they call, an illegitimate government.{{cite news|title=Հայաստանում ԱԺ ընտրություններն անցել են ընտրակեղծիքներով. "Հայազն" միություն ''(Hayazn: Election was held with major fraud)''|url=http://www.tert.am/am/news/2012/06/01/hayazn/|accessdate=13 December 2012|date=1 June 2012|agency=''Tert.am'|language=hy}} In June 2011, the union started to collect signatures for the citizenship of [[Jirair Sefilian]], a Lebanese-born Armenian military commander of the [[Nagorno-Karabakh War]]. More than 4,000 signatures were gathered.{{cite news|title=Hayazn collects signatures to back up Zhirayr Sefilyan’s bid for Armenian citizenship|url=http://www.panarmenian.net/eng/news/72514/Hayazn_collects_signatures_to_back_up_Zhirayr_Sefilyans_bid_for_Armenian_citizenship|accessdate=10 December 2012|date=15 June 2011|agency=''[[PanARMENIAN.Net]]''}} However, the relationship with Sefilian deteriorated, when on September 2, 2013 Hayazn members reportedly attacked and beat-up Varuszhan Avetisyan, the press secretary and member of the [[Pre-Parliament (Armenia)|Pre-Parliament]].[http://www.aravot.am/2013/09/03/282806 Ըստ «Նախախորհրդարանի»՝ «Հայազն» կուսակցության անդամները հարձակվել են իրենց մամուլի խոսնակի վրա] On September 1, 2012, Hayazn organized a protest during which several of its members burnt the [[Hungarian flag]] as an act of protest against [[Ramil Safarov]]'s release to Azerbaijan.{{cite news|title=Hungarian flag burned|url=http://www.a1plus.am/en/politics/2012/09/01/drosh|accessdate=14 December 2012|date=1 September 2012|agency=''[[A1plus]]''}} They also demanded the resignation of the Foreign Minister [[Eduard Nalbandyan]].{{cite news|title=Hayazn Union demands immediate resignation of Armenian Foreign Minister|url=http://www.arminfo.info/index.cfm?objectid=9F51E880-F428-11E1-9CECF6327207157C|accessdate=14 December 2012|date=1 September 2012|agency=''Arminfo''}}{{cite news|title=Citizens’ Fury Won’t Stop. Ramil Safarov shouldn’t have been extradited|url=http://www.1in.am/eng/armenia_asociety_1655.html|accessdate=14 December 2012|date=1 September 2010|agency=''[[1in.am]]''}} On May 21, 2012 Hayazn organized a parallel march in opposition to the first of its kind "Diversity march" organized by the [[LGBT]] community of Armenia. The march was stopped prematurely, because LGBT activists were afraid of their safety.[http://www.hra.am/hy/point-of-view/2012/05/22/bazmazanutyun Բռնության սպառնալիքների պատճառով «Բազմազանության շաբաթը» չի կայանա] On October 10, 2012, Hayazn organized a protest in front of [[Germany]]'s embassy in Yerevan by the union against the presentation of the film ''[[The Parade (film)|The Parade]]'' about gay activism in Serbia. The union stated that they would not tolerate "propaganda of immorality".{{cite news|title=Հայազն միություն. Չենք դադարեցնելու մեր պայքարը պղծությունների քարոզի դեմ ''(Hayazn: We Will not stop our struggle against the spread of immorality)''|url=http://www.panorama.am/am/society/2012/10/10/hayazn/|accessdate=14 December 2012|agency=''[[1in.am]]''}} During anti-Putin protests on December 2, 2013, several members of Hayazn attacked LGBT rights activist and demanded that they do not fly the [[Rainbow flag]] during the protests.[http://en.aravot.am/2013/12/04/162818/ Lala Aslikyan. “The rights of homosexuals are violated in CU member countries.” (Video)] Throughout spring 2013, Hayazn was a vocal opponent of leasing land in [[Syunik Province]] for Iranian pastures.{{cite news|title=Protest Demonstration Under "No Persian Sheep in Syunyats Gorge" Slogan|url=http://www.ecolur.org/en/news/dialog-with-officials/protest-demonstration-under-vno-persian-sheep-in-syunyats-gorgev-slogan/4575/|accessdate=28 April 2013|date=14 February 2013|agency=Ecolur}} Hayazn took an active role in the [[2013 Armenian protests|anti-government protests throughout 2013]]. On December 2, 2013 along with several political parties, they took to the streets to protest Russia's president [[Vladimir Putin]]'s visit to Armenia and Serzh Sargsyan's decision to join the [[Customs Union of Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Russia]].{{cite news|last=Avanesov|first=Alexandr|title=Armenian opposition to welcome Russian president with protests|url=http://www.arminfo.info/index.cfm?objectid=9C005840-5B26-11E3-9A420EB7C0D21663|accessdate=20 December 2013|newspaper=ArmInfo|date=2 December 2013}} ==See also== * [[National Revival (Artsakh)]] Nationalist party in [[Republic of Artsakh|Artsakh]]. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Armenian nationalism}} [[Category:2009 establishments in Armenia]] [[Category:Armenian nationalism]] [[Category:Conservative parties in Armenia]] [[Category:Nationalist parties in Armenia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2009]] [[Category:Political parties established in 2013]] [[Category:Political parties in Armenia]] [[Category:Organizations that oppose same-sex marriage]]

[[File:Independence - RLDS Temple 02.jpg|right|thumb|Community of Christ Temple in Independence, Missouri, USA. Dedicated 1994]] '''The Temple''' in Independence, Missouri, is a house of worship and education "dedicated to the pursuit of peace".[[Doctrine and Covenants]], Section 156:5 It dominates the skyline of [[Independence, Missouri]], [[United States|USA]], and has become the focal point of the headquarters of the [[Community of Christ]] (formerly, the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints[https://archive.is/20010422055040/http://cofchrist.org/news/q_and_a-churchname.asp Questions and Answers on Church Name Change]). The [[temple]] was built by the [[Community of Christ]] in response to a "revelation" presented to their 1984 [[World Conference (Community of Christ)|World Conference]] by church prophet-president [[Wallace B. Smith]]. The revelation culminated instructions shared over the course of more than 150 years by prior prophet-presidents recognized by the Community of Christ. [[Groundbreaking]] for the temple took place Friday 6 April 1990, and the completed structure was dedicated on Sunday 17 April 1994. ==Structure and building== [[File:TempleSpireCoC.jpg|right|frame|Looking up the spire from the sanctuary of the temple.]] The temple was designed by [[Gyo Obata]] and evokes the spiral shell of the [[Chambered Nautilus|Nautilus]] with a [[stainless steel]] [[spire]] that rises {{convert|300|ft|m}}.Chiat, Marilyn; ''North American Churches,'' Publications International, Ltd.:2004, p. 72. The facility displays art which comprises a collection of modern and traditional religious art from around the world. The entry to the sanctuary is through a beautifully etched glass archway depicting the Sacred Grove where [[Joseph Smith]] had his initial revelatory experience. This leads to the gently ascending worshiper's path of textured stone which spirals around its periphery. Along the path are artworks and a fountain symbolizing the "living water" of [[Gospel of John|John]] 4:10 for meditative focus. The temple's main sanctuary has seating for approximately 1,600. It houses a [[Casavant Frères|Casavant]] [[pipe organ]] with 60 stops, 102 ranks, and 5685 pipes. At the exit foyer in the mouth of the spiral, "The Field is White, Already to Harvest" (see John: 4:35) is a large stained glass wall depicting rice and wheat, that earned an American Institute of Architects award for religious art. Adjacent are the massive bronze exit doors which carry the church seal depicting the peaceful lion, lamb, and child from [[Isaiah]] 11:6 and the word "PEACE". The wide steps open up onto a world plaza with global map of inlaid brick. The public is welcomed to the temple, where there is a [[Daily Prayer for Peace]] at 1:00 p.m. Central Time on behalf of a selected nation of the world. A meditation chapel with paintings by Jack Garnier of the Sacraments being performed around the world opens onto a Japanese style meditation garden and serves the needs of individuals or small groups of visitors. The temple also contains the church archives, the Temple School, administrative offices of church headquarters, theaters used for visitors and also for meetings, presentations, and classes, a museum and gift shop. The building has become a popular attraction with guided tours available. Approximately 60,000 people visit the temple each year. ==Temple ministries== [[File:Independence - RLDS Temple 01.jpg|left|thumb|The Temple as seen from the [[Temple Lot]].]] The temple is regarded as a symbol of the church's mission and has long been closely associated with the denomination's developing theology of Zion, or the peaceable Kingdom of God, first advocated as [[basileia tou theou]] by [[Jesus Christ]]. The first major event held at the Temple prior to its dedication, was the International Women's Conference in June 1993. The Temple has no private ceremonies and is open to everyone. The sacraments performed there are Communion, Administration to the Sick (Laying on of Hands), and Ordination. Initially, six temple ministries centers were created in response to the building of the Temple. The temple according to Ken Robinson, former member of the First Presidency,"gives form to our commitment to Jesus Christ" and that it "is at the center of meaning and identity for members of the Community of Christ" Robinson, Kenneth N., "A People of the Temple," The Herald, July 2006, p. 12. {{cite web |url=http://www.cofchrist.org/SharePeace/Jul06/Robinson-People-of-Temple.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-07-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070929094215/http://www.cofchrist.org/SharePeace/Jul06/Robinson-People-of-Temple.asp |archivedate=2007-09-29 |df= }} ==Temple lot== {{quote box | quote = If ye are faithful, ye shall assemble yourselves together to rejoice upon the land of Missouri, which is the land of your inheritance, which is now the land of your enemies.

  — [[Doctrine and Covenants#Community of Christ editions|''Doctrine & Covenants'']] (Community of Christ edition), section 52, verse 9e{{cite web|url = https://user.xmission.com/~research/central/temple1.htm |title = The Independence Temple of Zion | author = [[H. Michael Marquardt]]|year = 1997}} | width = 34% | align = right }} [[Wallace B. Smith|Wallace B. Smith's]] great-grandfather and founder of the [[Latter Day Saint movement]], [[Joseph Smith]], visited [[Jackson County, Missouri|Jackson County]] in 1831 and prophesied that a temple to the Lord would be built there.[[Doctrine and Covenants]] (Community of Christ), Section 57:1d The early Latter Day Saints purchased a {{convert|73|acre|ha}} parcel of land known as the "greater [[Temple Lot|temple lot]]." At that time a portion of the property was dedicated as the site for a temple, and cornerstones were laid{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}. However, the church members were driven from the county before any construction began. The original temple site proper is now owned by the [[Church of Christ (Temple Lot)]]. The Community of Christ's temple is built on the greater temple lot, as is the [[Auditorium (Community of Christ)|Auditorium]], the headquarters chapel of the [[Church of Christ (Temple Lot)]] and a visitor center from [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]]. The Community of Christ also owns the [[Kirtland Temple|temple]] in [[Kirtland, Ohio]], the first temple actually built (rather than merely planned) by the Latter Day Saint movement, which continues to be a place of worship and education. As part of its educational ministry that site is open as a [[National Historic Landmark]]. ==Notes== ==References== *Laurie Smith Monsees, ''The Temple: Dedicated to Peace'', Herald House: 1993. {{ISBN|978-0-8309-0648-2}} *Marilyn Chiat, ''North American Churches'', Publications International, Ltd.: 2004, p. 72. *Michael J. Crosbie, ''Architecture for the Gods.'' (Watson-Guptill Publications: 2000), pp. 66–72. {{ISBN|0-8230-0290-X}} ==External links== {{Wikipedia books |1=Community of Christ }} {{Portal|Community of Christ}} *{{commonscat-inline|Independence Temple}} *[https://www.cofchrist.org/visit-temple-organ Temple pipe organ] {{Community of Christ}} {{Coord|39|05|27|N|94|25|35|W|display=title|region:US_type:landmark}} [[Category:20th-century Latter Day Saint temples]] [[Category:Churches in Independence, Missouri]] [[Category:Community of Christ temples]] [[Category:Latter Day Saint movement in Missouri]] [[Category:Peace symbols]] [[Category:Places of worship in Missouri]] [[Category:Religious buildings completed in 1994]] [[Category:Temple Lot]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Missouri]] [[Category:Museums in Jackson County, Missouri]] [[Category:Religious museums in Missouri]]

Upendra Tripathy | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | affiliations = | budget = US$47 million | volunteers = | slogan = | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = | name = International Solar Alliance | native_name_lang = hi | named_after = | image_size = | logo_size = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = ISA | founder = | founding_location = [[Paris, France]] | merger = | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | region_served = Countries between the [[Tropic of Cancer]] and [[Tropic of Capricorn|Capricorn]] | methods = | fields = [[Renewable energy]] | membership = 121 nations | membership_year = As of 2017 | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | secessions = | budget_year = 2016-17 | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers_year = | mission = | website = [http://www.isolaralliance.org/ International Solar Alliance] }} [[File:World map torrid.svg|thumb|World map with the [[torrid zone]], the area between the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, highlighted in red.]] The '''International Solar Alliance''' ('''ISA''') is an alliance of more than 121 countries initiated by [[India]], most of them being '''sunshine countries''', which lie either completely or partly between the [[Tropic of Cancer]] and the [[Tropic of Capricorn]]. The primary objective of the alliance is to work for efficient exploitation of [[solar energy]] to reduce dependence on [[fossil fuel]]s. This initiative was first proposed by [[Prime Minister of India|Indian Prime Minister]] [[Narendra Modi]] in a speech in November 2015 at [[Wembley Stadium]], in which he referred to sunshine countries as ''Suryaputra'' ("Sons of the Sun").<ref>{{Cite web|title = Narendra Modi's Speech at Wembley Stadium: As It Happened|url = https://blogs.wsj.com/indiarealtime/2015/11/13/live-blog-narendra-modis-speech-at-the-wembley-stadium/|website =Wall Street Journal|accessdate = 2015-11-18}}</ref> The alliance is a [[treaty]]-based [[inter-governmental organization]]. Countries that do not fall within the Tropics can join the alliance and enjoy all benefits as other members, with the exception of voting rights.<ref name = "BS1"/>
The initiative was launched by [[Prime Minister of India|Prime Minister]] [[Narendra Modi]] at the [[India–Africa Forum Summit|India Africa Summit]], and a meeting of member countries ahead of the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] in Paris in November 2015.<ref>{{citation|title=PM Narendra Modi and French President Francois Hollande to launch game changing solar alliance|url=http://economictimes.com/industry/energy/power/pm-narendra-modi-and-french-president-francois-hollande-to-launch-game-changing-solar-alliance/articleshow/49975568.cms|publisher=[[The Economic Times]]|date=30 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{citation|title=France, India to launch global solar alliance|url=http://reuters.com/article/idINKBN0TI0QR20151129?irpc=932|agency=Reuters|date=29 November 2015}}</ref> The framework agreement of the International Solar Alliance opened for signatures in [[Marrakech]], [[Morocco]] in November 2016, and 121 countries have joined.
==Headquarters== It is headquartered in India.<ref name="et-16nov16"/> In January 2016, [[Narendra Modi]], and the then [[President of France|French President]] [[François Hollande]] jointly laid the foundation stone of the ISA Headquarters and inaugurated the interim Secretariat at the National Institute of Solar Energy (NISE) in [[Gwal Pahari]], [[Gurugram]], [[India]]. The Indian government has dedicated five acres of land on the NISE campus for its future headquarters; it also has contributed {{INRConvert|1.75|b}} to the fund to build a campus and for meeting expenditures for the first five years.<ref>{{Cite press release|title=International Solar Alliance will be the First International and Inter-Governmental Organisation of 121 Countries to have Headquarters in India with United Nations as Strategic Partner|url = http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=135794|publisher=Press Information Bureau, [[National Informatics Centre]], Government of India}}</ref>
The alliance is also called International Agency for Solar Policy and Application (IASPA).<ref>{{Cite web|title = Reports: India to announce global solar power alliance|url = http://www.businessgreen.com/bg/news/2431974/reports-india-to-announce-global-solar-power-alliance|website = www.businessgreen.com|accessdate = 2015-11-18}}</ref>
==Objective== The focus is on solar power utilization. The launching of such an alliance in Paris also sends a strong signal to the global communities about the sincerity of the developing nations towards their concern about climate change and to switch to a low-carbon growth path. India has pledged a target of installing 100GW by 2022 and reduction in emission intensity by 33–35% by 2030 to let solar energy reach to the most unconnected villages and communities and also towards creating a clean planet.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 107 'sunshine countries' could weld together ahead of Paris meet to give shape to PM's vision – The Times of India|url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/107-sunshine-countries-could-weld-together-ahead-of-Paris-meet-to-give-shape-to-PMs-vision/articleshow/48796738.cms|website = The Times of India|accessdate = 2015-11-30}}</ref> India's pledge to the Paris summit offered to bring 40% of its electricity generation capacity (not actual production) from non-fossil sources (renewable, large hydro, and nuclear) by 2030.<ref>{{Cite web|title = India unveils global solar alliance of 120 countries at Paris climate summit|url = https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2015/nov/30/india-set-to-unveil-global-solar-alliance-of-120-countries-at-paris-climate-summit|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-12-01|first = Arthur|last = Neslen}}</ref> it is based on world co operation.
==Geographical importance== The area of Earth located in between the [[Tropic of Cancer]] and [[Tropic of Capricorn]] is called the tropical (torrid) zone. The points on the Tropic of Cancer are the northernmost points up to which the Sun can pass directly overhead. Similarly, the southernmost points are on the Tropic of Capricorn which follow the same criteria. Location at the north of the Tropic of Cancer shows the Sun appearing at the south of the zenith.<ref>{{Cite web|title = What is the significance of the Tropic of Cancer, Tropic of Capricorn, Arctic Circle and Antarctic Circle? (Beginner) – Curious About Astronomy? Ask an Astronomer|url = http://curious.astro.cornell.edu/physics/160-our-solar-system/the-earth/seasons/15-what-is-the-significance-of-the-tropic-of-cancer-tropic-of-capricorn-arctic-circle-and-antarctic-circle-beginner|website = curious.astro.cornell.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-30}}</ref> The sunniest countries of the world are on the African continent, ranging from Somalia- Horn of Africa-, east to Niger, west and north to Egypt.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Which countries receive the most sunlight?|url = http://earth.rice.edu/mtpe/geo/geosphere/hot/energyfuture/Sunlight.html|website = earth.rice.edu|accessdate = 2015-11-30}}</ref>
For India, the possible additional benefit from the alliance can be the strengthening ties and with the major African countries increase goodwill for India among them.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Modi to launch solar alliance on first day of Paris climate summit|url = http://www.livemint.com/Politics/v38XtCkGXRtXtxG60gLx9K/Modi-to-launch-solar-alliance-on-first-day-of-Paris-climate.html|website = http://www.livemint.com/|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = International Solar Alliance sign of India's leadership on global stage, say experts – Firstpost|url = http://www.firstpost.com/world/international-solar-alliance-sign-of-indias-leadership-on-global-stage-say-experts-2528060.html|website = Firstpost|accessdate = 2015-12-04}}</ref>
==Countries joined== The alliance is a [[treaty]]-based [[inter-governmental organization]].<ref name="et-16nov16">{{Cite web |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/energy/power/international-solar-alliance-opened-for-signing-in-morocco/articleshow/55457526.cms |title=International Solar Alliance opened for signing in Morocco |year=2016 |newspaper=The Economic Times |access-date=16 November 2016}}</ref> The framework agreement of the International Solar Alliance opened for signatures in [[Marrakech]], [[Morocco]] in November 2016, on the sidelines of the [[Marrakech Climate Change Conference]] (the twenty-second session of the Conference of the Parties, or COP 22). On its first day (15 November), sixteen countries signed the Agreement: [[India]], [[Brazil]], the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]], the [[Dominican Republic]], the [[Republic of Guinea]], [[Mali]]; [[Nauru]]; [[Niger]]; [[Tanzania]]; [[Tuvalu]]; [[Cambodia]]; [[Ethiopia]]; [[Burkina Faso]]; [[Bangladesh]] and [[Madagascar]].<ref name="et-16nov16"/> By 17 November, Guinea Bissau, Fiji, France,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://isolaralliance.org/countries_2.html|title=Allied Countries|website=isolaralliance.org|language=en|access-date=2017-05-19}}</ref> On November 6, 2017 India ' s External Affairs Minister Sushma Swaraj held a meeting with Guinea’s Foreign Minister, Mamady Toure. During the course of this meeting, Mamady Toure handed over Guinea’s Instrument of Accession to the India-initiated International Solar Alliance (ISA). Vanuatu and Liberia also signed the agreement.<ref name = "BS1">{{cite web|title=19 countries sign up for solar alliance|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/19-countries-sign-up-for-solar-alliance-116111701463_1.html|website=Business Standard India|accessdate=14 April 2017|date=17 November 2016}}</ref>
Subsequently, an additional 107 countries joined the agreement, including all major countries that lie between the tropics of Cancer and Capricorn, including [[Mexico]], [[Peru]], [[Chile]], Argentina, Paraguay, [[Brazil]], [[India]], [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]], and [[China]]. A conclave started from 30 November 2015 for the sunshine grouping, called the InSPA (International Agency for Solar Policy & Application).<ref>{{Cite web|title = 107 countries to join PM and his sunshine band in November – The Times of India|url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/107-countries-to-join-PM-and-his-sunshine-band-in-November/articleshow/48794733.cms|website = The Times of India|accessdate = 2015-11-30}}</ref>
===Parties who have signed/ratified the framework of ISA=== The following countries are the prospective members of this alliance who have signed the framework. Countries marked with a plus have also [[Ratification|ratified]] the framework.<ref>[http://isolaralliance.org/MemberCont.aspx ISA Prospective Member Countries]</ref> Myanmar is the latest country to join this alliance.
{{div col|colwidth=20em}} *{{ALG}} *{{AUS}} + *{{BAN}} + *{{BEN}} *{{BRA}} *{{BUR}} + *{{BDI}} + *{{CAM}} *{{CPV}} *{{CHA}} *{{CHI}} *{{CRC}} *{{COD}} *{{COM}} + *{{CUB}} + *{{DJI}} *{{DMA}} *{{DOM}} *{{EGY}} *{{GEQ}} *{{ETH}} *{{FIJ}} + *{{FRA}} + *{{GAB}} + *{{GAM}} *{{GHA}} + *{{GUI}} + *{{GBS}} *{{GUY}} + *{{IND}} + *{{CIV}} + *{{JPN}} *{{KIR}} *{{LIB}} *{{MAD}} + *{{MAW}} + *{{MLI}} + *{{MRI}} + *{{MOZ}} *{{NAM}} *{{NRU}} + *{{NLD}} *{{NIG}} *{{NGR}} + *{{PNG}} + *{{PER}} + *{{RWA}} + *{{STP}} *{{SEN}} *{{SEY}} + *{{SOM}} + *{{SSD}} + *{{SRI}} + *{{SUD}} + *{{SUR}} *{{TAN}} *{{TON}} *{{TOG}} + *{{TUV}} + *{{UGA}} + *{{UAE}} + *{{GBR}} *{{VAN}} *{{VEN}} + *{{YEM}} *{{ZMB}} {{div col end}}
Apart from these there are 55 other members, making a total of 121 members to the alliance.
== Initiatives and partnerships == The alliance has partnered with [[World Bank]] to launch Global Solar Atlas at an ISA event at the World Future Energy Summit in Abu Dhabi. Global Solar Atlas is a free online tool that displays annual average solar power potential at any location in the world and thus identify potential sites for solar power generation. World Bank announced "This tool will help governments save millions of dollars on their own research and provide investors and solar developers with an easily accessible and uniform platform to compare resource potential between sites in one region or across multiple countries."<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2017/01/17/new-world-bank-tool-helps-map-solar-potential|title=New World Bank Tool Helps Map Solar Potential|work=World Bank|access-date=2018-02-11|language=en}}</ref>
Riccardo Puliti, Senior Director and Head of the World Bank’s Energy & Extractives Global Practice said ''“The World Bank is seeing a surge of interest from our clients in solar power as a result of the dramatic cost decreases over the past few years. We hope that the Global Solar Atlas will help inform the crucial planning and investment decisions that will need to be taken over the next decade to shift to more sustainable forms of energy.”'' Piyush Goyal, Power Minister of India said ''“This new tool will assist governments and investors to obtain an initial indication of solar resource potential before carrying out their own more detailed analysis.”''
== Future targets == India, with the support of France, has invited nations to facilitate infrastructure for implementation of solar projects. The alliance has been committed $1 tn as investment, and it is committed to making the costs of solar power more affordable for remote and inaccessible communities. The alliance will endorse India in achieving its goal of generating 100GW of solar energy and 175GW of renewable energy by 2022. The countries shall support each other in research and development as well as other high level activities.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 107 'sunshine countries' may shape PM's vision|url = http://liveindia.in/107-sunshine-countries-may-shape-pms-vision|website = Live India|accessdate = 2015-11-30|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151208071012/http://liveindia.in/107-sunshine-countries-may-shape-pms-vision|archivedate = 8 December 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
It is also seen as an alliance by the developing countries to form a united front and to undertake research and development for making solar power equipment within developing countries.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Paris climate meet: India-led global solar alliance to counter developed nations|url = http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/world/paris-climate-meet-indialed-global-solar-alliance-to-counter-developed-nations/article7916353.ece|website = The Hindu Business Line|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref>
==Progress== On June 30, 2016, the alliance entered into an understanding with the [[World Bank]] for accelerating mobilization of finance for solar energy. The Bank will have a major role in mobilizing more than US $1000 billion in investments that will be needed by 2030, to meet ISA’s goals for the massive deployment of affordable solar energy.<ref name="pib-30-6-16">{{cite web | url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=146680 | title=International Solar Alliance Cell and World Bank Signs Declaration for Promoting Solar Energy | publisher=Press Information Bureau, Govt. of India | date=30 June 2016 | accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> Till date 48 countries have signed and 26 countries have ratified the Framework Agreement of the ISA. With ratifications by 15 countries, the ISA will become a treaty based inter-governmental international organisation and it will be recognized by UN legally to become fully functionable.
At the World Future Energy Summit (WFES) held in Abu Dhabi in January 2018, the government of India announced the establishment of a $350 million solar development fund to enable financing of solar projects.
