{{Use Australian English|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox Government agency | agency_name = Murray-Darling Basin Authority | nativename = MDBA | logo = | logo_width = | logo_caption = | seal = | seal_width = | seal_caption = | formed = December 2008 | date1 = | date1_name = | date2 = | date2_name = | preceding1 = Murray-Darling Basin Commission | preceding2 = | dissolved = | superseding = | jurisdiction = | headquarters = [[Canberra]] | employees = 321 (2016){{cite report|title=APS Statistical Bulletin 2015-2016|url=http://www.apsc.gov.au/about-the-apsc/parliamentary/aps-statistical-bulletin/statisticalbulletin1516/table2total|publisher=Australian Public Service Commission|date=September 2016}} | budget = {{A$}}280 m (2009–2010) | chief1_name = Phillip Glyde | chief1_position =
Chief Executive | parent_agency = [[Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources (Australia)|Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources]] | website = {{URL|http://www.mdba.gov.au/}} | footnotes = }} The '''Murray-Darling Basin Authority''' (MDBA) is the principal government agency in charge of managing the [[Murray-Darling Basin]] in an integrated and [[sustainable development|sustainable]] manner. The MDBA is an independent [[statutory authority|statutory agency]] that manages, in conjunction with the Basin states, the Murray–Darling Basin's water resources in the national interest. The MDBA reports to the Australian Government Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources. The MDBA is established under the federal ''Water Act (2007)'',{{cite web |url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2014C00043 |title=Water Act 2007 (Cth) |publisher=[[ComLaw]] |accessdate=22 May 2014}} which was introduced under the [[Howard Government]] as part of the [[Water security in Australia#National Plan For Water Security|National Water Plan for Water Security]]. The ''Water Act (2007)'' was a response to the [[drought in Australia|drought]] and the potential effects of [[climate change in Australia]].{{cite web | url = http://www.aph.gov.au/senate/committee/ec_ctte/water_licences/report/c01.htm | title = Sustainable management by the Commonwealth of water resources: Chapter 1 Background | date= 8 October 2010 | accessdate = 17 October 2010 | work = Environment and Communications References Committee | publisher = [[Parliament of Australia]] }} The law aimed to fulfill Australia's obligations under the [[Ramsar Convention on Wetlands]].{{cite news | url = http://www.smh.com.au/environment/water-issues/farmers-fear-water-act-priority-20101015-16nmo.html | title = Farmers fear water act priority | author = Lenore Taylor | accessdate = 17 October 2010 | date = 16 October 2010 | work = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] | publisher = [[Fairfax Media]] }} The 2007 Act was substantially amended in 2008.{{cite web |url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/C2008A00139 |title=Water Amendment Act 2008 (Cth) |publisher=[[ComLaw]] |accessdate=22 May 2014}} The Chief Executive of the MDBA is Phillip Glyde who replaced Dr Rhondda Dickson.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-27/phillip-glyde-appointed-new-mdba-ceo/6980092 | title = Senior public servant Phillip Glyde appointed new Murray-Darling Basin Authority CEO | work = ABC Rural | publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | date = 27 Nov 2015 | accessdate = 15 Jan 2016 }} The Chair of the MDBA is [[Neil Andrew]] who replaced [[Craig Knowles]] after his term as Chair expired in 2015. Andrew is a former [[Liberal Party of Australia|Liberal]] member of the [[Australian House of Representatives]] from March 1983 to October 2004. Whilst the MDBA is a Commonwealth Government agency, an inter-governmental Murray‑Darling Basin Ministerial Council (Ministerial Council) acts in an advisory role in preparing and implementing the Basin Plan by the MDBA. This Council comprises the Commonwealth Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources (who also chairs the council) and one minister from each of the basin states (Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, and South Australia) and the Australian Capital Territory. The Ministerial Council introduced the [[Murray-Darling Cap]] in response to the 1995 report titled "An Audit of Water Use in the Murray-Darling Basin".{{cite web |url=http://www.anra.gov.au/topics/water/pubs/state_technical/nsw_tecpage.html |title=Water - New South Wales - Water Technical Report |date=13 May 2009 |work=Australian Natural Resources Atlas |publisher=Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities |accessdate=6 July 2011 }} ==Role of the MDBA== [[File:Murray-catchment-map MJC02.png|thumb|right|Map of the Murray-Darling Basin]] With the creation of the MDBA in 2008, for the first time, a single [[inter-governmental]] body assumed responsibility for [[Environmental planning|planning]] the [[Integrated catchment management|integrated management]] of water resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. In addition to the Commission's former functions, the MDBA's role includes: * preparing, implementing and enforcing the Murray-Darling Basin Plan * advising the minister on the accreditation of state water resource plans * developing a [[water right]]s information service which facilitates water trading across the Murray-Darling basin * measuring and monitoring water resources in the basin * gathering information and undertaking research * educating and engaging the community in the management of the basin's resources. The Murray–Darling Basin Authority is an integral element of the Commonwealth Government's program ''Water for the Future'' which has four priorities; namely: # tackling [[climate change in Australia|climate change]] # supporting healthy rivers # using water wisely and # securing [[Water supply and sanitation in Australia|water supplies]].{{cite web | url = http://www.mdba.gov.au/about_the_authority | title = About the Murray–Darling Basin Authority | work = About us | publisher = Murray–Darling Basin Authority | date = December 2008 | accessdate = }} The MDBA also commissions research into aquatic science and is a source of information on Australian [[Freshwater ecosystem|freshwater biology]]. ==History== Since 1914, there have been various intergovernmental agreements relating to Murray‑Darling water resources. Prior to the formation of the Murray-Darling Basin Authority, institutional arrangements for water resources management lay with the five State and Territory governments in the Basin, with little co-ordination. In response to this problem, the Murray-Darling Basin Commission was established in January 1988 under the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement, with a charter to efficiently manage and equitably distribute River Murray water resources. Secondly, it was to protect and improve the water quality of the River Murray and its tributaries; and lastly to advise the Murray-Darling Ministerial Council on water, land and [[environmental management]] in the Basin.{{cite web | url = http://www.gwptoolbox.org/index.php?option=com_case&id=22&Itemid=9 | title = Australia: The Murray-Darling Basin Commission | author = Hooper, Bruce | work = Global Water Partnership | publisher = Integrated Resource Management Research Pty Ltd | date = | accessdate = }} The ''Water Amendment Act 2008'' was introduced in December 2008 to amend the ''Water Act 2007''.{{cite web | url = http://www.environment.gov.au/water/australia/water-act/key-features.html | title = Key features of the Water Act 2007 | accessdate = 17 October 2010 | date = 29 August 2009 | work = Department of Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities | publisher = Commonwealth of Australia }} This law transferred authority from the Murray-Darling Basin Commission to the Murray-Darling Basin Authority, creating an independent, [[expert]]-based body that would manage the Basin holistically for the first time.{{cite web | url = http://www.nwc.gov.au/www/html/2294-water-act-2007.asp | title = Water Act 2007 | date = | accessdate = 17 October 2010 | work = National Water Commission | publisher = }} As at November 2016, the MDBA is four years into the implementation phase of the Basin Plan. The MDBA has published major bodies of work including: * Basin environmental watering strategy * Annual environmental watering priorities * Constraints management strategy * New water trade operating rules The MDBA also established a water trading scheme across Basin states to increase [[Intensive farming#Water use efficiency|water use efficiency]]. {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} ==Murray-Darling Basin Plan== The Murray-Darling Basin Plan was signed off by [[Tony Burke]], Minister for Sustainability, Environment, Water, Population and Communities on 22 November 2012, and passed its final hurdle in the Australian Parliament on the 29 November 2012. Following is the history leading up to this significant occasion in the history of Australian water reform. On 8 October 2010, the MDBA released a major document entitled the ''Guide to the Proposed Murray-Darling Basin Plan'' outlining a plan to secure the long-term [[ecological health]] of the Murray-Darling Basin. The guide introduced cutting existing water allocations and increasing [[environmental flow]]s.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2010/10/12/3036291.htm | title = MDBA Chair explains water allocation cuts | author = Thomsen, Joseph | accessdate = 17 October 2010 | date = 12 October 2010 | work = [[ABC Goulburn Murray]] | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation }} The proposed plan was the first part of a three-stage process to address the problems of the Murray-Darling Basin; namely, over-allocation, prolonged drought, natural climate variability and climate change, leading to deteroriation of rivers, wetlands, forests and floodplains in the basin.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/06/3030629.htm | title = The Murray-Darling Plan explained | author = Clarke, Sarah and staff | date = 8 October 2010 | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | accessdate = 23 May 2011 }} The MDBA is responsible for preparing and overseeing the Basin Plan, a [[Legally binding|legally enforceable]] management plan. The main aim of the Plan (passed by the Australian Parliament in November 2012) is to return around 2,750 GL to the river system.{{cite web | url = http://mdba.gov.au/what-we-do/basin-plan}} The authority originally reported that the a volume of water as high as 7,600 gigalitres per year would bring long-term sustainability{{cite news | url =http://www.theage.com.au/national/scientists-push-for-strong-plan-on-murraydarling-20101130-18fbe.html | title = Scientists push for strong plan on Murray-Darling | author = Peter Ker | accessdate = 2 December 2010 | date = 1 December 2010 | publisher = The Age}} and would be the best scenario for the ecosystems of the basin but "would not be socially or economically viable".{{cite news | url =http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/paradise-possible-but-too-costly/story-fn59niix-1225936193100 | title =Paradise possible but too costly | author = Lanai Vasek | accessdate = 2 December 2010 | date = 9 October 2010 | publisher = The Australian}} The Basin Plan sets and enforces environmentally sustainable limits on the quantities of water that may be taken from Basin [[water resource]]s. It has Basin-wide environmental, [[water quality]] and [[Salinity in Australia|salinity]] objectives and aims to develop efficient [[water trading]] regimes across the Basin.{{cite web|url=http://www.mdba.gov.au/basin-plan-roll-out/water-quality-and-salinity |title=Murray- Darling river: Water quality management|accessdate=23 August 2016}} The plan includes requirements for state water resource plans and aims to improve water security for all Basin users.[http://download.mdba.gov.au/FactSheet_Murrumbidgee.pdf Summary of Murrumbidgee Region From the Guide to the proposed Basin Plan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110226095725/http://download.mdba.gov.au/FactSheet_Murrumbidgee.pdf |date=26 February 2011 }} The Basin Plan aims to achieve a balance between environmental, economic and social considerations .{{cite web | url = http://www.mdba.gov.au/basin-plan/plan-murray%E2%80%93darling-basin}} With the release of the ''Guide to the Proposed Murray-Darling Basin Plan'' there were a significant number of protests and voiced concerns in rural towns that the MDBA visited to present the proposed plan at consultation meetings.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/15/3039240.htm?section=justin | title = Tractor convoy as SA irrigators protest | date = 15 October 2010 | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | accessdate = 23 May 2011 }} In [[Renmark, South Australia|Renmark]], more than 500 people attended the Authority's first public consultation meeting in the local hotel that accommodated only 250 people. The draft plan proposed water buybacks of up to 35% in the [[Riverland]] area, forcing job losses and reduced flows to angry irrigators.{{cite news | title = Tractor protest at Renmark river meeting | url = http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/water-cuts-will-force-nation-to-import-vegies-growers-warn/story-e6frea83-1225938382301 | author1 = Todd, Adam | accessdate = 29 January 2011 | newspaper = [[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] | publisher = News Limited | date = 15 October 2010}} Over 5,000 people attended a meeting in [[Griffith, New South Wales|Griffith]] where the local Mayor, Mike Neville, said the plan would "obliterate" [[Murrumbidgee River|Murrumbidgee]] valley communities.{{cite news | title = Griffith irrigators vent anger | url = http://www.weeklytimesnow.com.au/article/2010/10/21/248661_water.html | author1 = Woods, Kim | author2 = Ainsworth, Michelle | author3 = Myers, Fiona | accessdate = 21 October 2010 | newspaper = The Weekly Times | publisher = News Limited | date = 20 October 2010}} Other groups also echoed this feeling, such as the Victorian Farmers Federation{{cite web | url = http://www.vff.org.au/newsite/policy_issues/murray_darling_basin_plan.php | title = VFF Declares War!: Stop the MDBA plundering | work = | date = | accessdate = 23 May 2011 | publisher = Victorian Farmers Federation | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120917131741/http://www.vff.org.au/newsite/policy_issues/murray_darling_basin_plan.php | archivedate = 17 September 2012 | df = dmy-all }} and the Wine Group Growers' Australia.{{cite web | url = http://www.wgga.com.au/news/pdf/WGGA%20Basin%20Plan%20Response%20-%2013%20Oct%202010.pdf | title = Federal Government urged ‘not to forget people’ in Basin Plan | work = Media Release | date = 13 October 2010 | accessdate = 23 May 2011 | publisher = Wine Group Growers' Australia | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110706113325/http://www.wgga.com.au/news/pdf/WGGA%20Basin%20Plan%20Response%20-%2013%20Oct%202010.pdf | archivedate = 6 July 2011 | df = dmy-all }} At the same time, there was also support for the draft plan by various groups, including the [[Australian Conservation Foundation]],{{cite web |url=http://www.wetrivers.unsw.edu.au/2010/11/basin-plan-support/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408191209/http://www.wetrivers.unsw.edu.au/2010/11/basin-plan-support/ |archivedate=8 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }} and [[Environment Victoria]].{{cite web | url = http://www.environmentvictoria.org.au/content/murray-darling-basin-plan-%E2%80%93-what%E2%80%99s-it-all-about | title = Murray-Darling Basin Plan – what's it all about? | date = 11 March 2010 | accessdate = 23 May 2011 | work = [[Environment Victoria]] | publisher = [[Government of Victoria (Australia)|Government of Victoria]] | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121031223823/http://environmentvictoria.org.au/content/murray-darling-basin-plan-%e2%80%93-what%e2%80%99s-it-all-about | archivedate = 31 October 2012 | df = dmy-all }} In legal advice, dated 25 October 2010, from the [[Australian Government Solicitor]],{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/documents/scribd.htm?id=40202825&key=key-10jhzy5h167m71kear3j | title = The role of social and economic factors in the basin plan | author1 = Orr, Robert [[Queen's Counsel|QC]] | author2 = Neville, Helen | date = 25 October 2010 | work = ABC News from the original [[Australian Government Solicitor]] | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | accessdate = 29 January 2011 }} the Government's reading is that the draft plan must give equal weight to the environmental, social and economic impacts of proposed cuts to irrigation. Environmentalists and South Australian irrigators say the Authority should stick to its original figure.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/26/3048954.htm?site=news | title = SA irrigators back Murray-Darling cuts | author = Om, Jason | date = 27 October 2010 | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | accessdate = 23 May 2011 }} In October 2010, a parliamentary inquiry into the economic impacts of the plan was announced.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/10/16/3040193.htm | title = Murray authority chairman faces uphill battle | author = Lee, Tim | accessdate = 25 October 2010 | date = 18 October 2010 | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation }} While, in November 2010, the Authority announced that it might be forced to push back the release of its final plan for the river system until early 2012.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/11/01/3054328.htm?section=justin | title = Basin authority flags delay to final plan | author = Binnie, Kerrin | date = 1 November 2010 | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | accessdate = 23 May 2011 }} Less than one month later, Mike Taylor, then Chair of the Authority, announced his decision to resign effective from the end of January 2011. In announcing his resignation, he cited his concerns that the Water Act made it difficult to balance the environmental and socio-economic impacts of cuts to water allocations aimed at rescuing rivers in the basin.{{cite news | url = http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/murray-darling-basin-boss-mike-taylor-resigns/story-e6frg6n6-1225966814825 | title = Basin authority Mike Taylor's resignation won't halt Murray-Darling water reforms, says PM | author1 = Kelly, Joe | author2 = Massola, James | date = 7 December 2010 | work = [[The Australian]] | publisher = [[News Limited]] | accessdate = 29 January 2011 }}{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2010/12/07/3086516.htm?section=justin | title = Murray-Darling boss resigns | author = Rodgers, Emma | work = ABC News | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | date = 7 December 2010 | accessdate = }} Of crucial concern was Taylor's desire to not oversee a process that returned less than 3,000 GL to the basin.{{cite news | url = http://www.theage.com.au/environment/water-issues/murraydarling-chair-resigns-leaving-reforms-in-turmoil-20101207-18nea.html | title = Murray-Darling chair resigns, leaving reforms in turmoil | author1 = Ker, Peter | date = 7 December 2010 | work = [[The Age]] | publisher = Fairfax Media | accessdate = 29 January 2011 }} Both the [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]], [[Julia Gillard]], and the Water Minister, [[Tony Burke]], rejected Taylor's concerns that the Water Act and the objectives of the Authority were compromised.{{cite news | url = http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2010/s3087241.htm | title = Murray-Darling Basin Authority head resigns | author1 = Colvin, Mark | author2 = Hawley, Samantha | date = 7 December 2010 | work = [[PM (ABC Radio)|PM]] | publisher = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | accessdate = 29 January 2011 | authorlink1 = Mark Colvin|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121208143606/http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2010/s3087241.htm|archivedate=8 December 2012}} In May 2011, The Wentworth Group of Concerned Scientists withdrew its support for the Murray Darling Basin Plan, who described the process as seriously flawed and a waste of taxpayers' money.{{cite news|title=Riverina mayor welcomes Murray Darling Basin Plan withdrawal|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/05/23/3223996.htm|accessdate=23 May 2011|work=ABC News|publisher=Australia Broadcasting Corporation|date=23 May 2011}} The Wentworth Group said they could not support the plan which they believed would cost billions and claimed that it would not fix the problems in the river system. The Wentworth Group wanted a minimum 4000 gigalitres of water returned to the river system but the group believed that it would not happen under the draft plan. In June 2011, a federal parliamentary committee (chaired by independent [[Tony Windsor]]) delivered its report to the Murray-Darling Basin Authority and its recommendations on water cutbacks in the basin. The committee was told river communities faced annihilation if 4,000 [[gigalitres]] was returned to the environment. The committee also reported that the health of the river system could be protected without the cuts.{{cite news|last=Lane|first=Sabra|title=Windsor report slams Murray-Darling authority|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/06/02/3233832.htm|accessdate=2 June 2011|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=2 June 2011}} The Australian Conservation Foundation says it is disappointed by the report delivered by the inquiry into the Murray-Darling river system. The Australian Conservation Foundation believes that buybacks are the most efficient way to save the basin.{{cite news|last=Om|first=Jason|title=Environmentalists angered by Murray-Darling review|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/06/02/3234171.htm|accessdate=2 June 2011|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=2 June 2011}} In November 2011, the draft plan was finally released. The plan proposes that 2,750 gigalitres per year be cut from water allocations over a period of seven years.{{Cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2011-11-28/draft-basin-plan-released/3698064 |title=Mixed response to Murray-Darling plan |author= |accessdate=28 November 2011 |date=28 November 2011 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation }} According to a study by [[Wentworth Group of Concerned Scientists|Wentworth Group]], the Commonwealth Government originally planned to start buying the 2,750 gigalitres of water and to increase groundwater extractions by 2,600 gigalitres at the same time in March 2011.[http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-01-18/scientists-want-manipulated-basin-plan-scrapped/3781476?section=sa Scientists want 'manipulated' Basin plan scrapped] - ''ABC News'', 19 January 2011. Many of the groundwater is linked to river systems, but the Plan does not count it in the models.:[http://www.wentworthgroup.org/uploads/Wentworth%20Group%20Statement%20on%20the%202011%20Draft%20Murray-Darling%20Basin%20Plan.pdf Wentworth Group Statement on the 2011 Draft Murray-Darling Basin Plan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120321075017/http://www.wentworthgroup.org/uploads/Wentworth%20Group%20Statement%20on%20the%202011%20Draft%20Murray-Darling%20Basin%20Plan.pdf |date=21 March 2012 }} {{Quote|The Plan does not incorporate in the modelling the impact that increasing groundwater extractions by over 2,600GL will have on surface water flows, many of the groundwater systems in the Basin are linked to river systems. The Plan [also] sets long term diversion limits on the assumption that there is no risk to river health from climate change.|Wentworth Group Statement on the 2011 Draft Murray-Darling Basin Plan}} In late May 2012, a revision of the plan was forwarded to state water ministers for review.{{Cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/rural/news/content/201205/s3512350.htm |title=Murray-Darling plan delivered to states |author=Anna Vidot and rural reporters |accessdate=29 May 2012 |date=28 May 2012 |work=ABC Rural |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation }} It did not alter the recommendation to return 2,750 gigalitres of water to the environment by cutting water entitlements. Following much negotiation between the Commonwealth and State governments and numerous submissions from interested stakeholders and the community,the Basin Plan finally became law in November 2012 and is now being implemented. ==See also== {{Portal|Australia|Sustainable development}} *[[Catchment Management Authority (New South Wales)]] *[[Catchment Management Authority (Victoria)]] *[[River Basin Management Plans]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.mdba.gov.au/ Official '''Murray-Darling Basin Authority''' website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090519024624/http://www.mdbc.gov.au/ Murray-Darling Basin Commission - archived website] * [http://rosenberg.ucanr.org/documents/II%20Craik.pdf An essay describing the MDBC's response to extreme drought conditions, Presented by Dr Wendy Craik in May 2008] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091015234159/http://www.pc.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0007/86749/13-chapter10.pdf An essay which details the Murray-Darling Basin Authority's Living Murray Initiative, presented at the Australian Government Productivity Commission's Roundtable Proceedings "Promoting Better Environmental Outcomes" by Wendy Craik in August 2008] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100925122333/http://mdba.gov.au/basin_plan The Basin Plan - Murray-Darling Basin Authority] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100926035651/http://mdba.gov.au/services/publications/more-information?publicationid=35 Guide to the Proposed Basin Plan - Murray-Darling Basin Authority] * [http://www.csiro.au/science/MDBscience.html Murray-Darling Basin Science - Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO)] * [http://www.clw.csiro.au/publications/waterforahealthycountry/FactSheets/wfhc-MDB4-Irrigation-2010.pdf Research to support Murray-Darling Basin industries and communities - CSIRO] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121031223823/http://environmentvictoria.org.au/content/murray-darling-basin-plan-%e2%80%93-what%e2%80%99s-it-all-about Murray-Darling Basin Plan - Environment Victoria] {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Australian Government Departments}} [[Category:Murray-Darling basin| Murray-Darling Basin Authority]] [[Category:Commonwealth Government agencies of Australia]] [[Category:Government agencies of Australia]] [[Category:Water in Australia]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Government agencies established in 2008]] [[Category:Water management authorities]]

{{BLP sources|date=October 2010}} '''Najah Wakim''' (born 1946) is the president and one of the founders of the Lebanese leftist group the [[People's Movement (Lebanon)|People's Movement]]. He is a secular Lebanese lawyer who believes in secular Arabist ideology.
He managed to defeat [[Nasim Majdalani]] in 1972's Lebanese parliamentary elections for the Orthodox seat, and he was a supporter of [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]].<ref>{{cite book| last = Gordon| first = David C.| title = The Republic of Lebanon: Nation in Jeopardy| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Vq4OAAAAQAAJ| year = 1983| publisher = Westview Press Croom Helm| isbn = 978-0-86531-450-4| page = 105| quote = Criticism of the government became increasingly vocal, and the power of traditional leaders began to be seriously challenged. In 1972 'Abd al-Majid al Rafi'i, a pro-Iraqi leftist, and Najah Wakim, a Nasserist, were elected to parliament. }}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last = Denoeux| first = Guilain| title = Urban Unrest in the Middle East: A Comparative Study of Informal Networks in Egypt, Iran and Lebanon| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=-MS_smEipbQC| year = 1993| publisher = State University of New York Press| isbn = 978-0-7914-1523-8| page = 239| quote = 6. Najah Wakim, a Greek Orthodox candidate to the parliamentary elections of 1972, won one of the seats allocated to his community in Beirut, thanks to the support of the Sunni electorate, while few Greek orthodox voted for him. }}</ref><ref>{{cite book| last = Petran| first = Tabitha| title = The Struggle Over Lebanon| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=cDiFAAAAIAAJ| year = 1993| publisher = Monthly Review Press,U.S.| isbn = 978-0-85345-651-3| page = 125| quote = In a Beirut constituency, Najah Wakim, twenty-six-year-old candidate of the Nasserist Union of Working Forces, won the Greek Orthodox seat, to the consternation of the community's leadership which charged he was elected by Muslim votes. }}</ref> He was not involved in any military work during the [[Lebanese Civil War]]. However, several death threats were issued against him and several attempts were made on his life most notably on October 1, 1987.<ref>{{cite news |title=Lawmaker kills assailant in Beirut home |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SJ&s_site=mercurynews&p_multi=SJ&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB72C6BEABAB018&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |newspaper=San Jose Mercury News |date=1987-10-01 |accessdate=2010-10-30 |quote=A Parliament member shot and killed an armed assailant who broke into his West Beirut apartment today in an apparent assassination attempt, police said. A police statement said Najah Wakim, a pro-Syrian leftist legislator, used a Soviet-designed automatic pistol to kill the attacker.}}</ref> In 1982, he highly opposed the Israeli invasion of Beirut and voted against the Israeli-supported presidential candidate [[Bashir Gemayel]]. He rejected the 1989 [[Taif agreement]] claiming it is an American-Syrian agreement that only enhanced sectarianism in Lebanon.<ref>{{cite web |title=Gemayel accuses Syria of sabotaging Taif Accord |url=http://www.lebanonwire.com/0410/04102004LW.asp |publisher=Lebanon Wire |date=2004-10-20 |accessdate=2010-10-30 |quote=Former MP and the head of the People's Movement, Najah Wakim, said Taif was not "the solution for the Lebanese crisis, but a document for distributing regional and international roles in Lebanon." "Taif did not provide any decisive solution for Lebanon's crisis because the main sponsors -- the U.S. and Syria -- had no intention of settling the crisis but wanted to divide influence and power in Lebanon between them... Security and foreign policy matters were handed to Syria and the rest, especially economic, was assumed by the U.S.," Wakim said.}}</ref> Wakim won the parliamentary elections in 1992 and in 1996.<ref>{{cite book| last = Johnson| first = Michael| title = All honorable men: the social origins of war in Lebanon| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zydtz0dDntQC| year = 2001| publisher = I.B.Tauris| isbn = 978-1-86064-715-4| page = 238| quote = The leftist Greek Orthodox member of parliament, Najah Wakim, a vocal critic of Hariri, also won, but with a reduced share of the vote compared with his 1992 result (MEED, 13 September 1996). }}</ref> He boycotted the elections in 2000, opposing Syrian interference in Lebanese affairs.<ref>{{cite book| last = Johnson| first = Michael| title = All honorable men: the social origins of war in Lebanon| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zydtz0dDntQC| year = 2001| publisher = I.B.Tauris| isbn = 978-1-86064-715-4| page = 246| quote = Najah Wakim, the radical Greek Orthodox member of parliament in Beirut, stood down in 2000 rather than tolerate what he described as Syrian interference in the electoral process. }}</ref> He is known for his very strict opposition of the whole Lebanese regime and sectarian leaders.
But in 1998 while in parliament, Wakim voted for the election of Pro-Syrian [[President]] [[Émile Lahoud]]. He maintains strong links to Lebanese pro-Syrian figures such as [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party of Lebanon|Lebanese Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party]] MP [[Assem Qanso]].
In 1999, he founded "The People's Movement",<ref>{{cite web |author=NOW Staff |title=What if there were a second government? |url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=5785 |publisher=NOW Lebanon |date=2007-07-04 |accessdate=2010-10-30 |quote=A staunch Arabist who describes himself as opposed to “everything,” Wakim founded the People’s Movement or Harakat as-Sha’ab in 1999. The People’s Movement is, admirably, one of the most confessionally diverse political parties in Lebanon.}}</ref> a leftist group that calls for changes in the Lebanese political system and for better relationships between Arab countries. In 2001, his office was burned by arsonists who were not identified.
Najah Wakim was not involved in the pro-Syrian nor the anti-Syrian rallies in March 2005. However after the Syrian withdrawal, he attacked the [[March 14 Alliance]] claiming that the Syrian interference has been replaced with an American invasion of Lebanon. Even though the 2005 elections held the election law of 2000, and with an Arab political position, he fought the 2005 elections alone against the Hariri-LF-[[Hezbollah]] allied list and lost. He also ran for the 2009 elections but lost against the sectarian allies in Beirut. In the current Lebanese political scandal, Najah Wakim is a strict supporter to Hezbollah's arms and a great opposer to the government, who is currently considered as pro-American by many Lebanese parties.
Najah Wakim is the author of three books: Al 'Alam Al Thalith Wal Thawra (The Third World and Revolution), Al Ayadi Al Sud (The Black Hands) which is a foray into the political corruption in Lebanon in the days of the prime minister Rafiq Al Hariri. The other book contains his speeches and essays and is called Al Wahm Wal Amal (Illusion and Hope). All three books are in Arabic.
==Books== * {{cite book |first=Najah |last=Wakim |title=Al 'Alam Al Thalith Wal Thawra |year=1982 |oclc=9974612 |publisher=Maʻhad al-Inmāʻ al-ʻArabī |location=Beirut }} * {{cite book |first=Najah |last=Wakim |title=Al Ayadi Al Sud |year=1998 |oclc=42397300 |publisher=Sharikat al-Maṭbūʻāt lil-tawzīʻ wa-al-Nashr |location=Beirut }} * {{cite book |first=Najah |last=Wakim |title=Al Wahm Wal Amal |year=2003 |oclc=52443317 |publisher=Dār al-Ādāb |location=Beirut }}
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wakim, Najah}} [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Lebanese Arab nationalists]] [[Category:Lebanese activists]] [[Category:Lebanese anti-Syrian activists]] [[Category:Lebanese left-wing activists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the Parliament of Lebanon]] [[Category:People's Movement (Lebanon) politicians]] [[Category:Political party founders]] {{Lebanon-politician-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} '''Nakaluluwag''' or ''nakakaluwag'' (variants: ''nakakaluwang'' or ''nakaluluwang'') is a [[Filipino people|Filipino]] [[ethic]] wherein the well-off are socially and morally obligated to help those in need. In [[Hiligaynon language|Hiligaynon]], the term is ''nakaalwan''. It comes from the blending of the Chinese concept of ''wo'' (peace and harmony),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://il.china-embassy.org/eng/sggg/t358216.htm|title=Harmonious World: China's Ancient Philosophy for New International Order|website=il.china-embassy.org|accessdate=21 August 2018}}</ref> the Malay culture of familiarity even to distant relatives and other clan members,<ref>{{cite EB1911 |first=Sir Hugh Charles |last=Clifford |title=Malays |volume=17 |pages=475–478|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/42854/42854-h/42854-h.htm#ar122}}</ref> and the Christian teaching of helping the poor.
== Background == There is a traditional Chinese belief that states that in order to have peace and harmony in a kingdom or empire, there should be no extremes in wealth and poverty. Thus, those who are wealthy should give some of their wealth to those living in destitution. Thus, the poor will not take arms and revolt against those living in opulence.
With the introduction of Christian teachings by the Spanish missionaries starting in the 16th Century, the indigenous Filipino ethic was somehow refined to benevolence to all those in need, in general. The term and its variants have been incorporated in a number of Tagalog idioms and proverbs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://eskwela-apc-nstp.wikispaces.com/Sawikain+at+Salawikain|title=Wikispaces|website=eskwela-apc-nstp.wikispaces.com|access-date=2008-08-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080914144824/http://eskwela-apc-nstp.wikispaces.com/Sawikain+at+Salawikain|archive-date=2008-09-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Through the Spanish and the American colonial periods, and even the Japanese Occupation, as linguistic categorization emerges in the Filipino language as a representation of Filipino world view and causality, the concept of "nakaluluwag" further modified social perception and thereby leads to a continual interaction between the Filipino language and philosophy.
In some Filipino artworks, those in need are pictured as tightly clinging to what they have, and come into grips.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filipinoartworks.com/custom2.html|title=Site Disabled - FreeServers|website=www.filipinoartworks.com|accessdate=21 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imagesphilippines.com/searchimage.php?flagsearch=1&search=poverty&x=0&y=0&logic=AND|title=poverty Philippines: Pictures, Photos, Images and Artworks - Displaying: 1 to 10|website=www.imagesphilippines.com|accessdate=21 August 2018}}</ref> While those who are well-off are pictured as willing to let go of some of their possessions for those in need. "Maluwag" or "maluwang" literally means lightly held, loose, or spacious. It may also imply sufficient freedom to move around or having a comfortable space to work on.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sulit.com.ph/forum/viewtopic.php?p=7313|archive-url=https://archive.is/20070814214946/http://www.sulit.com.ph/forum/viewtopic.php?p=7313|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-08-14|title=Advertising link |website=OLX.ph|}}</ref> The term implies willingness in giving and helping: "''maluwag sa kalooban''" and those familiar with [[accounting]] concepts often substitute the term "liquid" as in "''Liquid'' ka ba ngayon? Puede bang makahiram?" ("Are you ''liquid'' at this time? Can you lend me some amount?").
Even some Filipino grade school children form small informal cooperatives and do ''paluwagan'' which is essentially a group money lending scheme. However, the term ''magpaluwal'' has become synonymous with simple money lending, while the ethic ''nakaluluwag'' involves giving.
== Academic interpretations of Nakualuluwag == This Filipino ethic of giving includes some sacrifice on the part of the giver: the person giving (nakaluluwag) should at the very least, feel some discomfort. One should "get hurt" by his or her act of giving. Otherwise the essence of sacrifice will be absent.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dakilapinoy.wordpress.com/2008/08/08/ang-editoryal-bilang-lunsaran-ng-panunuri/|title=Ang Editoryal bilang Lunsaran ng Panunuri|date=8 August 2008|publisher=|accessdate=21 August 2018}}</ref> This is similar but not identical to the Christian [[lesson of the widow's mite]] present in the [[Synoptic Gospels]] ({{bibleverse||Mark|12:38-44}}, {{bibleverse||Luke|20:45-47}},{{bibleverse||Luke|21:1-4}}).
The concept also includes relativism: some may be poor but they can consider themselves "nakaluluwag" to those who are much poorer, as rendered in a Tagalog commentary<ref>http://www.bible.claret.org/bibles/bsp_pdf/2-OLD%20TESTAMENT/4-Mga%20Propeta/2_Jeremiah/2_Jer%2020-36.pdf {{dead link|date=August 2018}}</ref> on {{bibleverse||Jeremiah|24:1}}. Even Filipino converts to the Church of the Latter-Day Saints ([[Mormon]]) translates the phrase "the rich" as "nakaluluwag".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lds.org/conference/talk/display/0,5232,49-8-33-3,00.html|title=General Conference Sessions - Archive of Previous Conferences|first=The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day|last=Saints|website=www.lds.org|accessdate=21 August 2018}}</ref> Those taking the [[Conflict theory]] approach to the study of society may suspect the true intentions of the "nakaluluwag".<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bulatlat.com/2008/02/kalayaan-midya-si-jun-lozada |title=Archived copy |access-date=2008-08-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090106064506/http://www.bulatlat.com/2008/02/kalayaan-midya-si-jun-lozada |archive-date=2009-01-06 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> However, some consider more than the financial aspect of the concept.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.abante-tonite.com/issue/apr1708/entertainment_joe.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=2008-08-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724062604/http://www.abante-tonite.com/issue/apr1708/entertainment_joe.htm |archive-date=2010-07-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The ethic involves fulfillment in doing a social obligation.<ref>http://simplyrachel.onewickedsoul.com/wp/?p=172{{dead link|date=August 2018}}</ref> This Filipino concept appears to be present even for the Filipino emigrants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/55032/Engineer-sa-Pinas-janitor-sa-Canada|title=Engineer sa Pinas, janitor sa Canada|publisher=|accessdate=21 August 2018}}</ref>
According to [[Antonio Levy S. Ingles Jr.]] of [[De La Salle-College of Saint Benilde]],<ref>http://www.dls-csb.edu.ph{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> this Filipino ethic is priceless and may bring about peace and harmony during times of crisis. He claims that "it is a Filipino affirmation of a sustainable [[world view]] and global care-giving ethic".
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * {{cite web |first=Jose |last=A. Fadul |title=SITO.org Artchive: Tumulong sana ang mga Nakaluluwag! by Jose A. Fadul | website=SITO.org | date=8 February 2008 | url=http://www.sito.org/cgi-bin/egads/showart?show=jaf.0027 | access-date=21 August 2018}}
